awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Bacterial Flagellar Propulsion
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria such as Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium swim through a fluid by rotating their helical flagella. Understanding the swimming mechanism of bacteria with flagella is a challenging subject that involves interactions between the biological, engineering, mathematical, and physical sciences.  Although many scientists have studied bacterial swimming, experimental and theoretical studies have both shown that it is difficult to understand the dynamic behavior of the flagellum because of its complex geometry during locomotion, and many open questions remain.  This project will develop and validate improved mathematical models for such bacterial motility.
 
The goals of this project are to: (1) develop detailed mathematical models accompanied by the numerical schemes to understand bacterial motility by means of flagella; (2) analyze the complicated hydrodynamic interactions among multiple flagella arising from the cell body in fluids; (3) validate the models by comparing the results to experimental data; and (4) use these models to make predictions that will be verified by further experimentation. This project also heavily involves the development of an adaptive version of the generalized immersed boundary method which will find numerous applications in biological fluid dynamics such as supercoiling DNA dynamics. The new numerical algorithm will be freely distributed on-line within IBAMR software. The results obtained from this research on free swimming bacteria may provide new information about the spread of infections and biofilm formation, and may help to design nanomachines that are self-propelled by flagella.

por.por_cntn:
Swimming bacteria with flagella are self-propelled micro-swimmers in nature, and the swimming strategies of such bacteria vary depending on the number and the position of flagella on the cell body. Of the flagellated organisms, peritrichous bacteria such as E. coli swim through the fluid by rotating their helical flagella, each of which is driven by a rotary motor, turning either clockwise (CW) or counterclockwise (CCW). The rotation of these motors leads the cell either to swim forward by a flagellar bundle ('run') or reorient the swimming direction by motor reversals ('tumble').     

A broad range of scientists has studied bacterial swimming. Many things are known, for example, the structure and the power sources of the flagellar motor and the assembly of the filament. However, many open questions remain. For example, what is the role of the hook in flagellar bundling? Why does a flagellum undergo polymorphic transformations (local changes in helical wavelength, helical diameter, and chirality)? During the project award period, we specifically focused on the study of polymorphic transitions together with the role of a compliant hook, flagellar bundling and unbundling, and the development of a free swimmer.

Bacteria E. coli exploit the polymorphic transformations of helical flagella to explore their fluid environment. In these bacteria, a sequence of polymorphic forms appears consecutively as the cell runs and tumbles. During a run, the molecular motors that drive the flagella spin CCW, and the flagella form a normal flagellar bundle. Reversing one or more of these motors, from CCW to CW, initiates a tumble by inducing shape transformations of the associated filaments, from normal to semicoiled and then to curly 1 form. The next run begins when the motors switch back to CCW rotations, causing the flagella to revert from curly 1 back to normal forms.

We investigated the hydrodynamics of elastic flagella in the absence of the cell body when one or more flagella undergo a full cycle of polymorphic transformations described above. Our simulation results showed that the first polymorphic change caused by motor reversals from CCW to CW put the flagella into two separate bundles resulting in reorientation of a cell, as observed in nature. These separate bundles rejoin together after another reversal of those motors from CW to CCW. We also found that because of polymorphic transformations, flagella can unbundle smoothly while continuing to drive fluid away from the cell body. This in turn will allow a bacterium to disband its superflagellum while continuing to swim in a forward direction.

It has been reported that hook compliance is important in flagellar bundling. We found that there are constraints on both hook flexibility and hook length that determine whether the flagella can effectively bundle or not. If the hook is too rigid and short, then it only allows the adjacent flagella to form a bundle. To increase the range of scattered flagella for bundling, the hook is required to be sufficiently flexible and long. However, if the hook is too long and/or too flexible, the hook buckles and impairs flagellar bundling.

As a benchmark problem, we created a free swimmer that imitates the swimming motion of a monotrichous bacterium, Vibrio A.  Single­flagellated bacterium Vibrio A. propels itself by rotating a flagellar motor. The flagellar motor alternates the direction of rotation between CCW and CW, and this leads to the forward and backward directed swimming. Such bacteria can change the course of swimming as the hook experiences its buckling caused by the change of bending rigidity. We developed a comprehensive model of Vibrio A as a free swimmer, which consists of a cell body as a massive rigid body and a flagellum as an elastic rod. Our model was able to mimic the swimming pattern that is well matched with the experimental observations. Furthermore, we found the critical thresholds of the rotational frequency of the motor and the bending modulus of the hook for the buckling instability, and further investigated the dependence of the buckling angle and the reorientation of the swimming cell after buckling on the physical and geometrical parameters of the model.

Mathematical methods developed during the project period will find numerous applications in biological fluid dynamics, for example, sperm motility and dinoflagellate bacteria. The findings and simulation results from this project may help to answer the questions raised by biologists and engineers, which were not answered due to experimental limitations. Furthermore, the understanding of swimming mechanism of a free swimmer may help to design an important vehicle for drug delivery in nano-sciences.

The NSF award allowed the PI to work closely with a postdoc, train graduate students in fluid-structure interaction problems by developing courses and integrating the findings into the course materials. The PI also mentored female undergraduate students through the Women in Science and Engineering program in mathematical modeling of biological problems.
